results.title: Mallboy and sound design
results.brief_description: Speakers: Philip Brophy (Sound Designer) Vincent Girusso (Director/Writer) Fiona Eagger (Producer) discussing the decisions they made for the sound design of ‘Mallboy’. This was a presentation for Cinesonic conference 2000 filmed for research purposes only.

results.title: Cyberdelia
results.credit_line:
Steve Spangaro, director
Mike Collins, associate director
Milena Romanin, production manager
Susan King, interviews and research
Based on an original concept by Adem Jaffers
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Cyberdelia is a visceral encounter with the aesthetic and ideals of Melbourne underground cyber artists at the confluence of analogue and digital creative practice in 1991.

In blending artist interviews and works, this magazine style documentary explores visions of personal and cultural enhancement through transformative digital technologies. The imminent fusion of spirituality with technology; flesh with machine and psychedelia with cybernetics is confidently proclaimed.

Cyberdelia is a visual and aural feast with the film-makers channelling the post-modern mischief and transcendental yearnings of the ‘cyberdelic’ movement to radical stylistic effect. Stunning cyber artist works are liberally leveraged as both feature material and interstitial fodder. Low-budget analogue video editing and compositing tools are pushed to the limit while artist on-camera interviews are staged in bizarre fashion so as to maintain the feel of a ‘trip documentary’ from start to finish.

Cyberdelia stretches the boundaries of arts documentary to portray the brazen idealism and micro-processor powered creativity of these pre World Wide Web visionaries. Produced for community television and first broadcast on RMITV, Cyberdelia was later shown on SKA-TV and other Australian community television test transmissions. It was also selected for the Sixth Australian International Video Festival (1991).

Artists: Acid Death Bed, Misha Hollenbach, Troy Innocent (Cyber Dada), Natalie Jeremijenko, Adem Jaffers (Neuro), Jeff Jaffers (Third Eye), Dale Nason (Cyber Dada), Ollie Olsen (Third Eye) Captain ROM, Stelarc, Gus Till (Third Eye), Julian Wong, Christopher Wright and Max Q.

Cyberdelia was generously donated to ACMI by Cyberdelia Productions.

results.title: Burnout 2001
results.brief_description: Burnout 2001 is an interactive game which allows users to use a catalogue of authentic burnout movements to create various markings on the screen. A variety of vehicle’s available each having a particular speciality to their burnout.
results.description: Burnout 2001 is an interactive game which allows users to use a catalogue of authentic burnout movements to create various markings on the screen. A variety of vehicle’s available each having a particular speciality to their burnout.

results.title: This is my world
results.brief_description: Leanne is a virtual popstar. The artist dressed as the character Leanne (modeled on an anime character) sings a sorrowful pop song about her lonely world. The video is shot in the liminal no-place space of the Shopping Centre.
results.description: Leanne is a virtual popstar. The artist dressed as the character Leanne (modeled on an anime character) sings a sorrowful pop song about her lonely world. The video is shot in the liminal no-place space of the Shopping Centre.

results.title: Screen sports development workshop
results.creator_credit: Paul Fletcher and Public Programs - Events (Helen Simondson)
results.brief_description:
The SCREENSPORTS event is a unique, entertaining and informative ‘CINEMA EXPERIENCE’. SCREENSPORTS represents an historic leap in the marriage of live performance and technology. It has the potential to be an ACMI flagship pioneering new international standards in screen-based performance. Based on the highly successful Theatre Sports;live improvisation performance the Screensports concept draws on screen culture and the screen as the basis for live improvisation.

A troupe of actors are thrown into virtual worlds utilising the ACMI template sets and the globecaster technology. The actors use these sets as a stimulus for fast and hilarious improvisation.
Screen sports will be fun and informative and appeal to a wide range of people.
In order to develop the Screensports performance it is crucial to conduct a creative development workshop to produce the content for the live performance.

results.title: Pet shop
results.brief_description: A four screen looping animation work, Pet Shop pulls at the heart strings with its adorably cute 2D animated animals. Corompt’s work uses reductive and stylised modes of representation, exploring how we engage with these synthetic characters. The unquie relationship that exists between spectator and subject, inviting the spectator to partake in an unspoken agreement, where they may teeter on the boundary of the objectivity and empathy, simultaneously acknowledging its artifice, while at the same time participating in its pathos.
